007package renderer.pipeline;
008
009import renderer.scene.*;
010import renderer.scene.primitives.*;
011import static renderer.pipeline.PipelineLogger.*;
012
013import java.awt.Color;
014import java.util.List;
015import java.util.ArrayList;
016
017/**
018   Clip a (projected) {@link LineSegment} that sticks out of the
019   view rectangle in the image plane. Interpolate {@link Vertex}
020   color from any clipped off {@code Vertex} to the new {@code Vertex}.
021<p>
022   This clipping algorithm is a simplification of the Liang-Barsky
023   Parametric Line Clipping algorithm.
024<p>
025   This algorithm assumes that all {@code Vertex} objects have been
026   projected onto the {@link renderer.scene.Camera}'s image plane,
027   {@code z = -1}. This algorithm also assumes that the camera's view
028   rectangle in the image plane is
029   <pre>{@code
030      -1 <= x <= +1  and
031      -1 <= y <= +1.
032   }</pre>
033<p>
034   If a line segment's projected vertex has an {@code x} or {@code y}
035   coordinate with absolute value greater than 1, then that vertex
036   "sticks out" of the view rectangle. This algorithm will clip the
037   line segment so that both of the line segment's vertices are within
038   the view rectangle.
039<p>
040   Here is an outline of the clipping algorithm.
041<p>
042   Recursively process each line segment, using the following steps.
043<p>
044     1) Test if the line segment no longer needs to be clipped, i.e.,
045        both of its vertices are within the view rectangle. If this is
046        the case, then return true.
047        <pre>{@code
048               x=-1        x=+1
049                 |          |
050                 |          |
051             ----+----------+----- y = +1
052                 |     v1   |
053                 |    /     |
054                 |   /      |
055                 |  /       |
056                 | v0       |
057             ----+----------+----- y = -1
058                 |          |
059                 |          |
060        }</pre>
061<p>
062     2) Test if the line segment should be "trivially rejected". A line
063        segment is "trivially rejected" if it is on the wrong side of any
064        of the four lines that bound the view rectangle (i.e., the four
065        lines {@code x = 1}, {@code x = -1}, {@code y = 1}, {@code y = -1}).
066        If so, then return {@code false} (so the line segment will not be
067        rasterized into the framebuffer).
068<p>
069        Notice that a line like the following one is trivially rejected
070        because it is on the "wrong" side of the line {@code x = 1}.
071        <pre>{@code
072                           x=1
073                            |            v1
074                            |            /
075                 +----------+           /
076                 |          |          /
077                 |          |         /
078                 |          |        /
079                 |          |       /
080                 |          |      /
081                 +----------+     /
082                            |    /
083                            |  v0
084        }</pre>
085        But the following line is NOT trivially rejected because, even
086        though it is completely outside of the view rectangle, this line
087        is not entirely on the wrong side of any one of the four lines
088        {@code x = 1}, {@code x = -1}, {@code y = 1}, or {@code y = -1}.
089        The line below will get clipped at least one time (either on the
090        line {@code x = 1} or the line {@code y = -1}) before it is
091        (recursively) a candidate for "trivial rejection". Notice that
092        the line below could even be clipped twice, first on {@code y = 1},
093        then on {@code x = 1}, before it can be trivially rejected (by
094        being on the wrong side of {@code y = -1}).
095        <pre>{@code
096                           x=1
097                            |          v1
098                            |         /
099                 +----------+        /
100                 |          |       /
101                 |          |      /
102                 |          |     /
103                 |          |    /
104                 |          |   /
105                 +----------+  /
106                            | /
107                            |/
108                            /
109                           /|
110                          / |
111                        v0
112        }</pre>
113<p>
114     3) If the line segment has been neither accepted nor rejected, then
115        it needs to be clipped. So we test the line segment against each
116        of the four clipping lines, {@code x = 1}, {@code x = -1},
117        {@code y = 1}, and {@code y = -1}, to determine if the line segment
118        crosses one of those lines. We clip the line segment against the
119        first line which we find that it crosses. Then we recursively clip
120        the resulting clipped line segment. Notice that we only clip against
121        the first clipping line which the segment is found to cross. We do
122        not continue to test against the other clipping lines. This is
123        because it may be the case, after just one clip, that the line
124        segment is now a candidate for trivial accept or reject. So rather
125        than test the line segment against several more clipping lines
126        (which may be useless tests) it is more efficient to recursively
127        clip the line segment, which will then start with the trivial accept
128        or reject tests.
129<p>
130        When we clip a line segment against a clipping line, it is always
131        the case that one endpoint of the line segment is on the "right"
132        side of the clipping line and the other endpoint is on the "wrong"
133        side of the clipping line. In the following picture, assume that
134        {@code v0} is on the "wrong" side of the clipping line ({@code x = 1})
135        and {@code v1} is on the "right" side. So {@code v0} needs to be
136        clipped off the line segment and replaced by a new vertex.
137        <pre>{@code
138                             x=1
139                         v1   |
140                           \  |
141                            \ |
142                             \|
143                              \
144                              |\
145                              | \
146                              |  \
147                              |   v0
148        }</pre>
149        Represent points {@code p(t)} on the line segment between {@code v0}
150        and {@code v1} with the following parametric equation.
151        <pre>{@code
152                  p(t) = (1-t) * v0 + t * v1  with  0 <= t <= 1
153        }</pre>
154        Notice that this equation parameterizes the line segment starting
155        with {@code v0} at {@code t=0} (on the "wrong side") and ending
156        with {@code v1} at {@code t=1} (on the "right side"). We need to
157        find the value of {@code t} when the line segment crosses the
158        clipping line {@code x = 1}. Let {@code v0 = (x0, y0)} and let
159        {@code v1 = (x1, y1)}. Then the above parametric equation becomes
160        the two component equations
161        <pre>{@code
162                 x(t) = (1-t) * x0 + t * x1,
163                 y(t) = (1-t) * y0 + t * y1,  with  0 <= t <= 1.
164        }</pre>
165        Since the clipping line in this example is {@code x = 1}, we need
166        to solve the equation {@code x(t) = 1} for {@code t}. So we need
167        to solve
168        <pre>{@code
169                  1 = (1-t) * x0 + t * x1
170        }</pre>
171        for {@code t}. Here are a few algebra steps.
172        <pre>{@code
173                  1 = x0 - t * x0 + t * x1
174                  1 = x0 + t * (x1 - x0)
175                  1 - x0 = t * (x1 - x0)
176                       t = (1 - x0)/(x1 - x0)
177        }</pre>
178        We get similar equations for {@code t} if we clip against the other
179        clipping lines ({@code x = -1}, {@code y = 1}, or {@code y = -1})
180        and we assume that {@code v0} is on the "wrong side" and {@code v1}
181        is on the "right side".
182<p>
183        Let {@code t0} denote the above value for {@code t}. With this value
184        for {@code t}, we can compute the y-coordinate of the new vertex
185        {@code p(t0)} that replaces {@code v0}.
186        <pre>{@code
187                             x=1
188                        v1    |
189                          \   |
190                           \  |
191                            \ |
192                              p(t0)=(1, y(t0))
193                              |
194                              |
195                              |
196         }</pre>
197         Here is the algebra.
198         <pre>{@code
199                  y(t0) = (1-t0) * y0 + t0 * y1
200                        = y0 + t0 * (y1 - y0)
201                        = y0 + (1 - x0)*((y1 - y0)/(x1 - x0))
202         }</pre>
203         Finally, the new line segment between {@code v1} and the new
204         vertex {@code p(t0)} is recursively clipped so that it can be
205         checked to see if it should be trivially accepted, trivially
206         rejected, or clipped again.
207*/
208public class Clip_Line
209{
210   /**
211      If the {@link LineSegment} sticks out of the view rectangle,
212      then return a clipped version that is contained in the view
213      rectangle. The new, clipped {@link LineSegment} object is
214      returned wrapped in an {@link List} object.
215      <p>
216      At least one new clipped {@link Vertex} will be added to the
217      {@link Model}'s vertex list (and as many as four new vertices
218      may be added to the {@link Model}'s vertex list).
219      <p>
220      If the {@link LineSegment} is completely outside of the view
221      rectangle, then return an empty {@link List} object to
222      indicate that the {@link LineSegment} should be discarded.
223
224      @param model  {@link Model} that the {@link LineSegment} {@code ls} comes from
225      @param ls     {@link LineSegment} to be clipped
226      @return a clipped version of {@code ls} wrapped in an {@link List} object
227   */
228   public static List<Primitive> clip(final Model model,
229                                      final LineSegment ls)
230   {
231      // Make local copies of several values.
232      final int vIndex0 = ls.vIndexList.get(0);
233      final int vIndex1 = ls.vIndexList.get(1);
234      final Vertex v0 = model.vertexList.get(vIndex0);
235      final Vertex v1 = model.vertexList.get(vIndex1);
236
237      final double x0 = v0.x,  y0 = v0.y;
238      final double x1 = v1.x,  y1 = v1.y;
239
240      // 1. Check for trivial accept.
241      if ( ! ( Math.abs( x0 ) > 1
242            || Math.abs( y0 ) > 1
243            || Math.abs( x1 ) > 1
244            || Math.abs( y1 ) > 1 ) )
245      {
246         if (Clip.debug) logMessage("-- Trivial accept.");
247         return java.util.Arrays.asList(ls); // better than "return ls"
248      }
249      // 2. Check for trivial delete.
250      else if ( (x0 >  1 && x1 >  1)   // to the right of the line x = 1
251             || (x0 < -1 && x1 < -1)   // to the left of the line x = -1
252             || (y0 >  1 && y1 >  1)   // above the line y = 1
253             || (y0 < -1 && y1 < -1) ) // below the line y = -1
254      {
255         if (Clip.debug) logMessage("-- Trivial delete.");
256         return new ArrayList<Primitive>();  // better than "return null"
257      }
258      // 3. Need to clip this line segment.
259      else
260      {
261         // Recursively clip a new (clipped) line segment.
262         return clip(model, clipOneTime(model, ls));
263      }
264   }
265
266
267   /**
268      This method takes in a line segment that crosses one of the four
269      clipping lines. This method returns a new LineSegment that uses
270      a new, interpolated, Vertex that is the intersection point between
271      the given LineSegment and the crossed clipping line.
272      <p>
273      This method solves for the value of {@code t} for which the
274      parametric equation
275      <pre>{@code
276                  p(t) = (1-t) * v_outside + t * v_inside
277      }</pre>
278      intersects the crossed clipping line. (Notice that the equation
279      is parameterized so that we move from the outside vertex towards
280      the inside vertex as {@code t} increases from 0 to 1.) The solved
281      for value of {@code t} is then plugged into the parametric formula
282      to get the coordinates of the intersection point.
283      <p>
284      The new interpolated Vertex is added to the end of the vertex list
285      from the given Model.
286
287      @param model  {@link Model} that the {@link LineSegment} {@code ls} comes from
288      @param ls     the {@link LineSegment} being clipped
289      @return a new clipped {@link LineSegment} object
290   */
291   private static LineSegment clipOneTime(final Model model,
292                                          final LineSegment ls)
293   {
294      // Make local copies of several values.
295      final int vIndex0 = ls.vIndexList.get(0);
296      final int vIndex1 = ls.vIndexList.get(1);
297      final Vertex v0 = model.vertexList.get(vIndex0);
298      final Vertex v1 = model.vertexList.get(vIndex1);
299
300      final double x0 = v0.x,  y0 = v0.y,  z0 = v0.z;
301      final double x1 = v1.x,  y1 = v1.y,  z1 = v1.z;
302
303      final String equation;   // keep track of which edge is crossed
304      final int    vOutside;   // keep track of which vertex is on the outside
305      final double vOx, vOy, vOz; // "O" for "outside"
306      final double vIx, vIy, vIz; // "I" for "inside"
307      final double t;          // when we cross the clipping line
308      final double x;          // x-coordinate of where we cross the clipping line
309      final double y;          // y-coordinate of where we cross the clipping line
310      final double z;          // z-coordinate of where we cross the clipping line
311      final int vIndexNew;     // index for the new, interpolated, vertex
312
313      if (x0 > 1)  // ls crosses the line x = 1
314      {
315         equation = "x = +1";
316         vOutside = 0;
317         vOx = x0;  vOy = y0;  vOz = z0;
318         vIx = x1;  vIy = y1;  vIz = z1;
319         t = (1 - vOx) / (vIx - vOx);
320         x = 1;  // prevent rounding errors
321         y = (1 - t) * vOy + t * vIy;
322         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
323         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
324         // Modify the Model to contain the new Vertex.
325         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
326         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
327      }
328      else if (x1 > 1)  // ls crosses the line x = 1
329      {
330         equation = "x = +1";
331         vOutside = 1;
332         vIx = x0;  vIy = y0;  vIz = z0;
333         vOx = x1;  vOy = y1;  vOz = z1;
334         t = (1 - vOx) / (vIx - vOx);
335         x = 1;  // prevent rounding errors
336         y = (1 - t) * vOy + t * vIy;
337         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
338         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
339         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
340         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
341      }
342      else if (x0 < -1)  // ls crosses the line x = -1
343      {
344         equation = "x = -1";
345         vOutside = 0;
346         vOx = x0;  vOy = y0;  vOz = z0;
347         vIx = x1;  vIy = y1;  vIz = z1;
348         t = (-1 - vOx) / (vIx - vOx);
349         x = -1;  // prevent rounding errors
350         y = (1 - t) * vOy + t * vIy;
351         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
352         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
353         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
354         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
355      }
356      else if (x1 < -1)  // ls crosses the line x = -1
357      {
358         equation = "x = -1";
359         vOutside = 1;
360         vIx = x0;  vIy = y0;  vIz = z0;
361         vOx = x1;  vOy = y1;  vOz = z1;
362         t = (-1 - vOx) / (vIx - vOx);
363         x = -1;  // prevent rounding errors
364         y = (1 - t) * vOy + t * vIy;
365         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
366         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
367         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
368         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
369      }
370      else if (y0 > 1)  // ls crosses the line y = 1
371      {
372         equation = "y = +1";
373         vOutside = 0;
374         vOx = x0;  vOy = y0;  vOz = z0;
375         vIx = x1;  vIy = y1;  vIz = z1;
376         t = (1 - vOy) / (vIy - vOy);
377         x = (1 - t) * vOx + t * vIx;
378         y = 1;  // prevent rounding errors
379         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
380         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
381         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
382         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
383      }
384      else if (y1 > 1)  // ls crosses the line y = 1
385      {
386         equation = "y = +1";
387         vOutside = 1;
388         vIx = x0;  vIy = y0;  vIz = z0;
389         vOx = x1;  vOy = y1;  vOz = z1;
390         t = (1 - vOy) / (vIy - vOy);
391         x = (1 - t) * vOx + t * vIx;
392         y = 1;  // prevent rounding errors
393         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
394         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
395         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
396         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
397      }
398      else if (y0 < -1)  // ls crosses the line y = -1
399      {
400         equation = "y = -1";
401         vOutside = 0;
402         vOx = x0;  vOy = y0;  vOz = z0;
403         vIx = x1;  vIy = y1;  vIz = z1;
404         t = (-1 - vOy) / (vIy - vOy);
405         x = (1 - t) * vOx + t * vIx;
406         y = -1;  // prevent rounding errors
407         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
408         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
409         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
410         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
411      }
412      else // if (y1 < -1)  // ls crosses the line y = -1
413      {
414         equation = "y = -1";
415         vOutside = 1;
416         vIx = x0;  vIy = y0;  vIz = z0;
417         vOx = x1;  vOy = y1;  vOz = z1;
418         t = (-1 - vOy) / (vIy - vOy);
419         x = (1 - t) * vOx + t * vIx;
420         y = -1;  // prevent rounding errors
421         z = (1 - t) * vOz + t * vIz;
422         final Vertex newVertex = new Vertex(x, y, z);
423         vIndexNew = model.vertexList.size();
424         model.vertexList.add(newVertex);
425      }
426
427      // Use the value of t to interpolate the color of the new vertex.
428      final int cIndexI = ls.cIndexList.get(1 - vOutside);
429      final int cIndexO = ls.cIndexList.get(    vOutside);
430      float cI[] = model.colorList.get(cIndexI).getRGBColorComponents(null);
431      float cO[] = model.colorList.get(cIndexO).getRGBColorComponents(null);
432      final float t_ = (float)t;
433      final float r = (1 - t_) * cO[0] + t_ * cI[0];
434      final float g = (1 - t_) * cO[1] + t_ * cI[1];
435      final float b = (1 - t_) * cO[2] + t_ * cI[2];
436
437      // Modify the Model to contain the new Color.
438      final Color newColor = new Color(r, g, b);
439      final int cIndexNew = model.colorList.size();
440      model.colorList.add(newColor);
441
442      if (Clip.debug)
443      {
444         final String vOut = (0==vOutside) ? "v0" : "v1";
445         logMessage(
446            String.format("-- Clip off %s at %s", vOut, equation));
447         logMessage(
448            String.format("-- t = % .25f", t));
449         logMessage(
450            String.format("-- <x_i, y_i, z_i> = <% .24f, % .24f, % .24f>",
451                               vIx, vIy, vIz));
452         logMessage(
453            String.format("-- <x_o, y_o, z_o> = <% .24f, % .24f, % .24f>",
454                               vOx, vOy, vOz));
455         logMessage(
456            String.format("-- <x_c, y_c, z_c> = <% .24f, % .24f, % .24f>",
457                               x,   y,   z));
458         logMessage(
459            String.format("-- <r_i, g_i, b_i> = <% .15f,  % .15f,  % .15f>",
460                              cI[0], cI[1], cI[2]));
461         logMessage(
462            String.format("-- <r_o, g_o, b_o> = <% .15f,  % .15f,  % .15f>",
463                              cO[0], cO[1], cO[2]));
464         logMessage(
465            String.format("-- <r_c, g_c, b_c> = <% .15f,  % .15f,  % .15f>",
466                               r,   g,   b));
467      }
468
469      // Return a new LineSegment using the new Vertex and Color and
470      // keeping the old LineSegment's inside Vertex and Color.
471      final LineSegment newLS;
472      if (1 == vOutside)
473      {
474         newLS = new LineSegment(vIndex0, vIndexNew,
475                                 cIndexI, cIndexNew);
476      }
477      else
478      {
479         newLS = new LineSegment(vIndexNew, vIndex1,
480                                 cIndexNew, cIndexI);
481      }
482      return newLS;
483   }
484
485
486
487   // Private default constructor to enforce noninstantiable class.
488   // See Item 4 in "Effective Java", 3rd Ed, Joshua Bloch.
489   private Clip_Line() {
490      throw new AssertionError();
491   }
492}
